BC-ZIMBABWE-REVIEW-NYT 
POWER IN BLACK AND WHITE 

  (The Week in Review) 
(NOTE TO INTERNATIONAL CLIENTS: For use by special arrangement
only. Asian and European points: Call Karl Horwitz in Paris for
details and prices, phone: 47 42 17 11; fax: 47-42-80-44). Latin
American points: Call Olivia Vasquez in Los Angeles, phone:
310-996-0075; fax: 310-996-0089). 
 By RACHEL L. SWARNS    
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   DURBAN, South Africa _ On the radio waves and television
screens, the conflict often appears stark and simple: The battle in
Zimbabwe, it seems, is a battle between blacks and whites.

   The aggressors are the landless black supporters of President
Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. Their enemies are the prosperous white
farmers, who own more than half of that country's fertile land. The
issue is land redistribution and the prominent victims are white
men whose haggard faces feature on the evening news here in
Zimbabwe's neighbor, South Africa, and abroad.

   But what, then, accounts for the predominantly black body count?

   Over the last month, 11 people have been killed in Zimbabwe. Of
those victims, only two were white. In reality, the people bearing
the brunt of that country's seething political violence are poor,
landless and overwhelmingly black.

   The truth is that the struggle in Zimbabwe is less about race
and land than it is about one ruling party's struggle to keep its
virtual monopoly of power. For while Mugabe rages about the white
enemy, his supporters have quietly recognized that ordinary blacks
pose the more potent political threat.

   It is the black majority that has the power to end the ruling
party's overwhelming control of Parliament in coming elections, now
tentatively scheduled for May. And for the first time in 20 years,
the ordinary blacks of Zimbabwe _ who are weary of soaring
inflation, deepening poverty and government corruption _ seem
inclined to do just that. Most of the blacks who died were killed
because they opposed Mugabe's government.

   ``You have a situation where more and more black people are
saying, `Let's get rid of this government,''' said John Makumbe, a
political science professor at the University of Zimbabwe. ``And
violence is being perpetrated against them.''

   The whole land and race issue is a classic diversion of
attention from the real issues which are facing this country, high
levels of unemployment, inflation and poverty,'' Makumbe said.
``What you really have is a government under siege trying to
survive.''

   Opponents of the government call it old-style despotism. And it
rings a strikingly discordant note in a corner of the world where
democracy and freedom of political expression has flourished in
recent years.

   Last year, four democracies here at the foot of the continent _
South Africa, Botswana, Namibia and Mozambique _ elected presidents
in contested elections that were deemed free and fair.

   And leaders from this region who have willingly and freely given
up power _ men like Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Sir Ketumile
Masire of Botswana _ are winning respect as elder statesmen as they
mediate conflicts in Burundi and Congo.

   And then there is Mugabe, who once inspired and sheltered black
freedom fighters across the region. But today, as he and his allies
support illegal land invasions of white-owned farms and stand by
without condemning attacks on opposition party members, many people
cannot help but shake their heads.

   Mugabe and his party, many critics say, have become too hungry
for power.

   ``He's almost a caricature of all the things people think black
African leaders do,'' said Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa.
``He seems to be wanting to make a cartoon of himself.

   ``I am shattered because Mugabe is one of the most highly
qualified and most able leaders,'' Tutu said, in remarks to
European journalists that were published in news reports here.
``One just wants to weep. It's very sad.''

   Mugabe's governing party currently controls all but three seats
in Parliament. But it seems likely that voters will whittle away at
that dominant position.

   In February, voters handed Mugabe his first political defeat
since he became president 20 years ago. They rejected a
constitutional amendment that would have expanded his powers and
allowed the government to seize white-owned land without
compensation.

   The serious attacks on black opponents began within weeks of
that defeat. And government critics say the ruling party has
deliberately played down those killings, hoping to distract the
public with vigorous rhetorical attacks on Zimbabwe's white
minority, who dominate the economy but make up less than 2 percent
of the population.

   The black victims include an electrician, a policeman, a
pregnant woman and the driver of Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition
party leader; they were killed in clashes with supporters of the
government. Last week, two people were stoned to death.

   The killings typically receive only cursory mention in
Zimbabwe's government-controlled media and little coverage in the
foreign press, according to the Media Monitoring Project of
Zimbabwe, which monitors news coverage about that country.

   Newspapers like The Daily News, Zimbabwe's only independent
daily, have reported more extensively on the deaths, noting they
are typically politically motivated with little to do with race or
land.

   But on April 22, the office of the Daily News was firebombed.
The government detained a South African photographer in connection
with the explosion, which shattered the newspaper's windows, but
injured no one.

   But journalists at the newspaper, which is critical of the
government, blame supporters of Mugabe. Two weeks ago, the
newspaper's editor in chief, who is black, received a death threat,
warning him to stop criticizing the government.

   ``I don't think race is the primary thing,'' said William Saidi,
the assistant editor of the Daily News. ``The general plan is to
silence all opposition.''
